mental point on which J udaism and Christianity differed was the Divinity of Christ.

1. Verum neque de Christo erubescimus. Op. Rom. i. 163 2Tim. i. 83 Luke’ lx. 26.

quum: ‘since we rejoice . . .’ Quum brings forward an evidence of verum meque . . .

2. deputari. Either ‘ to be assigned,' ‘ reckoned,' as in last ch.‚ etc.; see note3 or with an ellipse of in poenam = ‘ to be condemned,' as in Capitol. Macrin. 12, ‘servos . . . ad gladium ludi deputavit' ; cp. de cult.fem. i. 2, ⁶ damnati in poenam mortis deputantur!

aliter, vae. otherwise than do the Jews.

4. de Christo ut Deo. cp. ch. 2 with note, and Pliny’s letter to Trajan.

10. [ad delirandum] Added in cod. Fuld. Other edd. read ad declinandum, or omit altogether.

derivantes: ‘ turning aeide! The metaphor is that of a river flowing out of its wonted course, and is a parallel one to that contained in exorbitare ; see note, ch. 6.

12. Dispersi, palabundi. On the state of the Jews in Tertullian’s day see adv. Jud. 2, 133 de pudic. 8; Euseb. H. E. iv. 6 (the edict of Hadrian after the revolt of Barchochebas), τὸ πᾶν ἔθνος ἐξ ἐκείνου καὶ τῆς περὶ τὰ Ἱεροσόλυμα γῆς πάμπαν ἐπιβαίνειν εἴργεται, νόμου δόγματι καὶ διατάξεσιν Ἀδριανοῦ, ὡς ἂν μηδ’ ἐξ ἀπόπτου θεωροΐεν τὸ πατρῷον ἔδαφος, ἐγκελευσαμένου. On one day only in the year—the anniversary of the destruction of J erusalem—,could the prohibition be evaded ς see Vales. ad Euseb. l. c. ; cp. Just. Mart. Apol. i. 62.

13. sine homine. Corrected by Scaliger (perhaps unnecessarily) into sine nomine .- one Lyon MS. inserts sine again before reqe. Cp. 1 Sam. viii. 6, 73 Hos. iii. 43 x. 3.
